abstract.p: Ralph M Vitello letter disagrees with Herbert Muschamp's August 13 article on Frank Gehry's proposal for new Guggenheim museum (S)

block.p: Much as I enjoyed reading Herbert Muschamp's evocative article on Frank Gehry's proposal for a new Guggenheim museum [''Living Up to the Memories of a Poetic Old Skyline,'' Aug. 13], I must disagree with its central premise. Much as I enjoyed reading Herbert Muschamp's evocative article on Frank Gehry's proposal for a new Guggenheim museum [''Living Up to the Memories of a Poetic Old Skyline,'' Aug. 13], I must disagree with its central premise. Unlike the Brooklyn Bridge, the Gehry proposal is sorely lacking in two elements intrinsic to all great architecture: beauty and form.

Mr. Muschamp justifies his parallel with the Brooklyn Bridge by means of a convoluted conceptual frame involving ethos and eidos. A more appropriate critical term would be bathos. As presented in the initial plans, Mr. Gehry's proposal for a new Guggenheim is a crass rehashing of what has already been built in Bilbao, Spain. Rather than creating a link to past or future, it would stick out like a sore thumb, a glittering architectural hangnail dangling in the river.
